reviewText:
It looked like a perfect title to me, so I grabbed it on sight. A combination of Audiosurf's nimble flying and n's greed for shiny blocks? With great visuals and nice soundtrack? Count me in!

There's an important thing to note, though. Futuridium's unique turn-around mechanic is interesting, but it comes with a twist: you're not nimble at all.

How do I steer fast, captain?
The ship you're guiding is slow. Don't get me wrong - you can boost forward and reach impressive speeds, but it doesn't change your maneuverability. The game forces you to use the 180° turn all the time, so you must flip a switch in your brain and start planning your flight in zigzag patterns.

Getting used to this game mechanic is a long and difficult process. You will feel powerless trying to shoot down targets (cyan blocks) that are seemingly right next to you, only to find out the ship won't make it there, even at its lowest speed. Only then the basic idea of turning back starts to stick, and you slowly learn to fly back and forth to chain the longest possible combo of destroyed blocks.

And don't you even dare brush too close to them. You will crash and respawn at the very beginning, which - for levels with very long intro" sections - means repetitve
date: boring flight that drains your very limited energy. Trying to enter a group of 5 blocks to shoot down at least two of them is almost guaranteed crash
recommended:
but may let you hold on to that sweet combo for more points.

Wait. Energy?
You better not wait
hoursPlayed: because your lifespan within a single level is limited to 120 seconds. During these two minutes you need to fly around
voteText: evade obstacles and annihilate all shiny blocks
helpfulPercent: which reveals the final block - the enemy ship's core - that resets your energy meter and wipes off the enemy dreadnought when it's shot down.\n\nI'm not sure why it's called energy meter
votesHelpful: when it's literally showing remaining time. Even shooting and boosting doesn't impact its level
votesTotal: which seems a bit counterintuitive for the name. On the other hand
votesFunny: this means you can keep spraying your laser guns and use boost to your heart's content
column16: the only other energy consumer is zero-distance contact with other space bodies. Crashing into things costs half of your remaining energy
column17: so it's better to make three safe passes back and forth than risking halving your life in a single flight. Well
column19: until you get a grip on the controls.\n\nShooting down one of the ubiquitous blocks increases your lifespan by one second
column20:
which is a gamechanger on lengthy boss levels.

They're shooting back!
The levels (enormous enemy ships) come in multiple forms. There are flat board(s) with blocks on either side
column22: and bonus sectors with your almost nonexistent energy refilling at numbered rings. You can even encounter wrecks of spaceships
column23: where all cyan blocks are scattered around the wreckage.\n\nIf crashing and limited energy weren't enough
column24: there are also turrets that spew lasers and shoot homing rockets at you. While the lasers almost always miss (Stormtroopers?)
column25: the rockets can easily catch up to the ship if you forget to boost and turn around often. There are also balls that inflate into large
column26: impenetrable spheres of doom - a major headache
column27: so they should be destroyed on sight.\n\nSome levels have moving parts
column28: which need to be considered in your path calculations; otherwise
column29:
doing a 180° turn may end with an unpleasant surprise.

Where did the keyboard go?
It would be awesome if you had a controller lying around
column30: because the whole game will only communicate pad controls to you. Y for leaderboards
column32: X to turn around. The built-in help shows a pad
column33: and there's no way to change - hell
column34: even view - the keyboard bindings.\n\nYou have to find them yourself instead! Good luck. I found that N and M change music
column37: and C changes camera. I wish I knew how to access leaderboards from the keyboard.\n\nThere's no built-in way to change bindings
column38: but there must be some .ini file that will let you do it the old way
column39: right? Haha. No. Use AutoHotkey instead.\n\nThe store page doesn't mention that the game basically requires a controller. The developers said they're looking into implementing some sort of keyboard support
column41: Steam Controller allows customization around existing pad controls
column42: not only keyboard keys. If you have SC
column43:
this drawback won't affect you the slightest.

Conclusion
If you're used to quick-reaction games like Super Hexagon or Velocibox
column44: you will have a hard time adapting to Futuridium's rules. Perfecting a level means careful path planning
column45: not just pressing a button when a wall appears. You will often feel frustrated when trying to aim at blocks that appear so close
column46: but are way too far to get to them.\n\nHowever
column48: shooting stuff and zigzagging around enemies suddenly gets fun
column49: and scoring your first perfect chain in a long level feels great.\n\nThe game offers multiple colorful skins and background music
column50: both of which you can change at will. I would prefer it if the skin didn't randomize on each retry
column51: but that's a minor gripe - at least the blocks are always distinguishable.\n\nFuturidium's learning curve is rather steep right from the beginning
column52: so grab your controller tight and give your roommates a warning before running the game.\n\nYou'll be swearing a lot."

reviewText:
Futuridium EP Deluxe:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Some people like flying, some people have outstanding reflexes. Well, if this is one of your combinations, “Futuridium EP Deluxe” is going to be fun and challenging for you, my friends!

Futuridium EP Deluxe is an action / space type of game where you take control of a spaceship. You will have to shoot sky blue squares, located on, under and around large vessels, as fast as possible to reveal its core (white cube), destroy it and win the level! You will have 50 to clear in total.

At the start of each level your own vessel will fly rather slowly but you will be able to use the boost button (on your gamepad) to go faster. As the aim of the game is to finish each level as fast as possible, you probably will think this is great, but you will lose a fair bit of manoeuvrability and might accidently crash into the ship (I have done that a number of times). The trick lies in how good you are at controlling your ship and, let me tell you it will take you quite a while to get used to it, especially the 180 back flip. Boy I got this wrong over and over! Well, what can you do when you have only 3 fingers (the beauty of being an amphibian)!

But to make the experience as simple as possible (I am being very sarcastic here) you have turrets and missile launchers returning fire. That is where you have to have great reflexes with your gamepad (no keyboard supported). On the top right corner will be displayed the energy bar which is really your countdown. So if you did not manage to get all the blue cubes plus the core and there is no energy bar left – well, it will be game over! However, every blue cube you blast will add energy to your bar, which is some sort of relief I guess.

The controls are responsive and the soundtrack is really good.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	50 colourful levels to beat
-	Great soundtrack
-	Achievement and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Frustrating at times

This is a rather difficult game but fun to play.

7/10

Futuridium EP Deluxe is a challenging and fun game to play. Good reflexes needed.

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText: It is always a nice treat to play a game that lives up to what it promises. Even if Futuridium is light in story, it excels in flight and level design. This makes for a great combination of game play and strategy. Small levels and quick thinking await you in this methodical shoot-em up.
